### Subsection: 10.1a Introduction to Superstrings

Superstrings are a fundamental concept in string theory, extending the concept of strings to include spin-1/2 particles. They were first proposed by Michael Green and John Schwarz in 1984, building upon the work of Edward Witten and Luis Álvarez-Gaumé in the early 1980s. Superstrings have played a crucial role in the development of string theory, leading to the discovery of M-theory and the realization of the holographic principle.

#### 10.1a.1 The First Superstring Revolution

The first superstring revolution, which took place in the early 1980s, was a pivotal moment in the history of string theory. It was during this period that physicists began to understand the true potential of string theory as a theory of quantum gravity. This revolution was largely driven by the work of Edward Witten, who became convinced that string theory was a consistent theory of gravity after discovering a contribution to the anomaly that had been missed by Green and Schwarz.

During this period, physicists also discovered heterotic strings, which have a gauge group of two copies of E8. These strings were found to naturally include the standard model, and they paved the way for the discovery of M-theory.

#### 10.1a.2 The Second Superstring Revolution

The second superstring revolution, which took place in the 1990s, was another significant moment in the history of string theory. This revolution was largely driven by the work of Joseph Polchinski, who discovered the concept of M-theory. M-theory is a theory of eleven-dimensional supergravity, and it is the theory that unifies all the other string theories.

The second superstring revolution also saw the development of the concept of holographic duality, which is a fundamental concept in string theory. Holographic duality is a concept that suggests that all the information about a system can be encoded in its boundary. This concept has been instrumental in the development of string theory and has led to many important insights.

#### 10.1a.3 Superstrings and Holographic Duality

Superstrings play a crucial role in holographic duality. The AdS/CFT correspondence, which is a specific example of holographic duality, is based on the concept of superstrings. The AdS/CFT correspondence suggests that a theory in a higher-dimensional anti-de Sitter space is dual to a theory in a lower-dimensional conformal field theory. This correspondence has been instrumental in the development of string theory and has led to many important insights.

In conclusion, superstrings are a fundamental concept in string theory, and they have played a crucial role in the development of the theory. The first and second superstring revolutions have been pivotal moments in the history of string theory, leading to the discovery of M-theory and the concept of holographic duality. Superstrings continue to be a topic of active research, and they hold great promise for the future of string theory.





### Subsection: 10.1b Dualities in String Theory

Dualities play a crucial role in string theory, providing a deeper understanding of the underlying principles and symmetries of the theory. They are mathematical transformations that relate different descriptions of the same physical system. In this section, we will explore some of the most important dualities in string theory, including T-duality, S-duality, and the holomorphic anomaly.

#### 10.1b.1 T-duality

T-duality is a symmetry of the theory that exchanges the strong and weak coupling regimes of the theory. It is a symmetry of the equations of motion of the theory, and it is closely related to the concept of duality in quantum mechanics. T-duality is particularly important in the context of topological string theory, where it is used to relate the A-model and B-model on two mirror manifolds.

The A-model and B-model on the same manifold are conjectured to be related by S-duality, which implies the existence of several new branes, called NS branes by analogy with the NS5-brane. These branes wrap the same cycles as the original branes but in the opposite theory. This duality also involves a combination of the A-model and a sum of the B-model and its conjugate, which are related to topological M-theory by a kind of dimensional reduction.

#### 10.1b.2 S-duality

S-duality is another symmetry of the theory that exchanges the strong and weak coupling regimes of the theory. It is closely related to T-duality and is particularly important in the context of the A-model and B-model on the same manifold. S-duality implies the existence of several new branes, called NS branes by analogy with the NS5-brane.

#### 10.1b.3 Holomorphic Anomaly

The holomorphic anomaly is a phenomenon that arises in the low energy effective action of the B-model. It states that the dependence on complex quantities, while classically holomorphic, receives nonholomorphic quantum corrections. This structure is analogous to a structure that one finds geometrically quantizing the space of complex structures. Once this space has been quantized, only half of the dimensions simultaneously commute and so the number of degrees of freedom has been halved. This halving depends on an arbitrary choice, called a polarization. The conjugate model contains the missing degrees of freedom, and so by tensoring the B-model and its conjugate one reobtains all of the missing degrees of freedom and also eliminates the dependence on the arbitrary choice of polarization.

In the next section, we will explore the concept of holographic duality, which is a fundamental concept in string theory. Holographic duality is a concept that suggests that all the information about a system can be encoded in its boundary. This concept has been instrumental in the development of string theory, leading to the discovery of M-theory and the realization of the holographic principle.





### Subsection: 10.1c M-theory and 11-dimensional Supergravity

M-theory is a theoretical framework that attempts to unify all the fundamental forces of nature, including gravity, into a single theory. It is based on the concept of 11-dimensional supergravity, a theory that describes the interactions of particles in an 11-dimensional spacetime. This theory is a natural extension of the 10-dimensional supergravity theory that is used in string theory.

#### 10.1c.1 11-dimensional Supergravity

11-dimensional supergravity is a theory that describes the interactions of particles in an 11-dimensional spacetime. It is a theory of supergravity, meaning that it includes both gravitational and supersymmetric interactions. The theory is based on the supergravity multiplet, which consists of the graviton, the gravitino, and the dilaton.

The theory is described by the equations of motion derived from the action:

$$
S = \frac{1}{2\kappa^2} \int d^{11}x \sqrt{-g} \left( R + \frac{1}{2}(\partial\phi)^2 + \frac{1}{4}e^{-2\phi}F^2 \right)
$$

where $g$ is the determinant of the metric, $R$ is the Ricci scalar, $\phi$ is the dilaton, and $F$ is the field strength of the 3-form potential.

#### 10.1c.2 M-theory

M-theory is a theoretical framework that attempts to unify all the fundamental forces of nature, including gravity, into a single theory. It is based on the concept of 11-dimensional supergravity, but it also includes additional structures such as membranes and five-branes.

The theory is described by the equations of motion derived from the action:

$$
S = \frac{1}{2\kappa^2} \int d^{11}x \sqrt{-g} \left( R + \frac{1}{2}(\partial\phi)^2 + \frac{1}{4}e^{-2\phi}F^2 + \cdots \right)
$$

where the dots represent additional terms that describe the interactions of the membranes and five-branes.

M-theory is still a subject of ongoing research, and many of its details are not yet fully understood. However, it is a promising approach to the unification of all fundamental forces, and it has led to many important insights into the nature of space and time.




### Subsection: 10.2a Compactification on Calabi-Yau Manifolds

In the previous section, we discussed the concept of M-theory and its connection to 11-dimensional supergravity. In this section, we will explore the concept of compactification, specifically on Calabi-Yau manifolds, which is a crucial aspect of string theory.

#### 10.2a.1 Compactification

Compactification is a fundamental concept in string theory that allows us to study strings in lower-dimensional spaces. This is achieved by compactifying the extra dimensions of the string theory into smaller, finite spaces. This is necessary because the equations of motion for strings are only solvable in spaces of ten or more dimensions.

The compactification process involves the introduction of a compact manifold into the theory. This manifold is typically chosen to be a Calabi-Yau manifold, which is a complex manifold with special properties that make it particularly suitable for compactification.

#### 10.2a.2 Calabi-Yau Manifolds

Calabi-Yau manifolds are a class of compact, complex manifolds that are of great importance in string theory. They were first introduced by the mathematician Eugenio Calabi in the 1950s, and later studied in depth by the physicist Shing-Tung Yau.

A Calabi-Yau manifold is a Kähler manifold that is Ricci-flat. This means that the Ricci curvature of the manifold is zero everywhere. This property is crucial for the compactification of string theory, as it allows us to preserve the symmetries of the theory.

#### 10.2a.3 Mirror Symmetry and Calabi-Yau Manifolds

The concept of mirror symmetry, which we briefly mentioned in the previous section, is closely related to Calabi-Yau manifolds. Mirror symmetry is a proposal in string theory that suggests that certain pairs of Calabi-Yau manifolds are related in a special way. This relationship is characterized by the equality of certain numerical invariants, such as the Euler number and the Hodge number.

The physicists Philip Candelas, Xenia de la Ossa, Paul Green, and Linda Parkes proposed a formula of enumerative geometry that encodes the number of rational curves of any fixed degree in a general quintic hypersurface of four-dimensional complex projective space. This formula is a manifestation of the mirror symmetry conjecture.

The works of Givental and of Lian-Liu-Yau confirm the mirror symmetry conjecture for three-dimensional Calabi-Yau manifolds. However, their works do not logically depend on the conjecture itself, and so have no immediate bearing on its validity.

#### 10.2a.4 The SYZ Conjecture

The SYZ conjecture, proposed by Shing-Tung Yau, Andrew Strominger, and Eric Zaslow, provides a geometric picture of how mirror symmetry might be systematically understood and proved to be true. According to the SYZ conjecture, a Calabi-Yau manifold with complex dimension three should be foliated by "special Lagrangian" tori, which are certain types of three-dimensional minimal submanifolds of the six-dimensional Riemannian manifold underlying the Calabi-Yau manifold.

The SYZ conjecture is still a subject of ongoing research, and its full implications are not yet fully understood. However, it provides a powerful tool for understanding the structure of Calabi-Yau manifolds and their role in string theory.

In the next section, we will explore another important aspect of string theory: the concept of D-branes.




### Subsection: 10.2b Compactification on Tori and Orbifolds

In the previous section, we discussed the concept of compactification on Calabi-Yau manifolds. In this section, we will explore another important type of compactification: compactification on tori and orbifolds.

#### 10.2b.1 Compactification on Tori

A torus is a simple geometric object, a doughnut-shaped space. In string theory, tori are often used as compactification spaces. The reason for this is that the equations of motion for strings can be solved on a torus, and the resulting theory is often simpler than the theory on a Calabi-Yau manifold.

Compactification on a torus is achieved by identifying the extra dimensions of the theory with the coordinates of the torus. This identification is made through a periodicity condition, which states that the extra dimensions must repeat themselves after a certain distance.

#### 10.2b.2 Orbifolds

An orbifold is a generalization of the concept of a manifold. It is a space that locally looks like a manifold, but globally may have singularities. In string theory, orbifolds are often used as compactification spaces.

The concept of an orbifold is closely related to the concept of a symmetry group. In string theory, the symmetry group of a theory is often used to construct an orbifold. The orbifold is then defined as the quotient space of the theory by the symmetry group.

#### 10.2b.3 Compactification on Orbifolds

Compactification on an orbifold is achieved by identifying the extra dimensions of the theory with the coordinates of the orbifold. This identification is made through a periodicity condition, similar to the one used for tori.

The advantage of compactification on orbifolds is that it allows for a more general class of compactification spaces than compactification on tori. This is because orbifolds can have more complex singularities than tori, which can lead to more interesting and diverse theories.

In the next section, we will explore the concept of compactification on Calabi-Yau three-folds, which is another important type of compactification in string theory.




### Subsection: 10.2c Flux Compactifications and Moduli Stabilization

In the previous sections, we have discussed compactifications on Calabi-Yau manifolds, tori, and orbifolds. These compactifications are achieved by identifying the extra dimensions of the theory with the coordinates of the respective spaces. However, in many cases, these compactifications do not lead to a stable theory. The reason for this instability is the presence of moduli, which are parameters that describe the shape of the compactification space. These moduli can take any value, leading to an infinite number of possible compactifications. This is in contrast to the finite number of possible compactifications on a torus or orbifold.

To address this issue, we can introduce fluxes into the theory. Fluxes are additional fields that couple to the moduli and can stabilize them. This process is known as flux compactification. The fluxes can be thought of as background fields that permeate the compactification space. They can be turned on or off, and their strength can be adjusted to stabilize the moduli.

The fluxes can be classified into two types: geometric fluxes and non-geometric fluxes. Geometric fluxes are those that can be described by the geometry of the compactification space. They include the RR and NSNS fluxes in type II string theory, and the complex structure and Kahler moduli in Calabi-Yau compactifications. Non-geometric fluxes, on the other hand, cannot be described by the geometry of the compactification space. They include the axion-dilaton field in type II string theory, and the complex structure and Kahler moduli in Calabi-Yau compactifications.

The presence of fluxes can lead to interesting phenomena, such as the formation of domain walls and the breaking of supersymmetry. These phenomena can be studied using the techniques of string duality, which we will discuss in the next section.

In the next section, we will also discuss the concept of moduli stabilization in more detail. We will explore how fluxes can be used to stabilize the moduli and lead to a stable theory. We will also discuss the role of fluxes in the construction of string vacua, which are solutions of the equations of motion of the theory.




### Subsection: 10.3a D-branes and T-duality

In the previous sections, we have discussed the concept of branes and their role in string theory. We have also explored the concept of T-duality, which is a symmetry of the theory that relates different descriptions of the same physical system. In this section, we will delve deeper into the relationship between D-branes and T-duality.

#### D-branes and T-duality

D-branes are a type of brane that plays a crucial role in string theory. They are objects that extend in one or more spatial dimensions and can carry various quantum numbers, such as charge and momentum. D-branes are particularly important in the study of string theory because they provide a way to describe the dynamics of open strings.

T-duality, on the other hand, is a symmetry of the theory that relates different descriptions of the same physical system. It is particularly useful in the study of branes, as it allows us to relate the properties of branes in different descriptions of the same physical system.

The relationship between D-branes and T-duality can be understood in terms of the concept of duality frames. A duality frame is a set of coordinates and conventions that describe a physical system. In the case of D-branes, there are two duality frames: the type IIB frame and the type IIA frame.

In the type IIB frame, D-branes are described as objects that extend in one or more spatial dimensions and carry various quantum numbers. These branes are related to the type IIA frame through T-duality. In the type IIA frame, the same branes are described as objects that extend in one or more spatial dimensions and carry different quantum numbers. This relationship between the two frames is known as T-duality.

### Subsection: 11.1a Holography as a Principle of Quantum Gravity

Holography is a fundamental principle in quantum gravity that has been instrumental in the development of AdS/CFT. It is a principle that suggests that the information about a system can be encoded in a lower-dimensional surface, known as the holographic surface. This principle has been used to derive the AdS/CFT duality, which provides a powerful tool for studying quantum systems.

#### The Holographic Principle

The holographic principle is a conjecture in quantum gravity that suggests that the information about a system can be encoded in a lower-dimensional surface. This principle is based on the idea that the information about a system is not spread out throughout the system, but is instead concentrated on the boundary of the system. This is analogous to the way information is stored on a holographic film, where the information is encoded in the surface of the film, not in the volume of the film.

The holographic principle has been used to derive the AdS/CFT duality, which provides a powerful tool for studying quantum systems. The AdS/CFT duality states that certain quantum systems can be described by a theory of gravity in an anti-de Sitter space. This duality has been used to study a wide range of quantum systems, from condensed matter systems to black holes.

#### The Holographic Principle and Quantum Gravity

The holographic principle has important implications for quantum gravity. It suggests that the fundamental theory of quantum gravity should be a theory of quantum information, not a theory of quantum mechanics. This is because the holographic principle implies that the fundamental degrees of freedom in a quantum system are not the particles of the system, but the bits of information about the system.

The holographic principle also has implications for the structure of quantum space. It suggests that quantum space is not a continuum, but a discrete set of points, each of which represents a bit of information. This is analogous to the way a holographic film is made up of a discrete set of pixels, each of which represents a bit of information.

#### The Holographic Principle and the Quantum Master Constraint

The holographic principle is closely related to the quantum master constraint, a key concept in loop quantum gravity. The quantum master constraint is a constraint on the quantum state of a system that ensures the consistency of the system. It is defined as

$$
\hat{M} \Psi = 0
$$

where $\hat{M}$ is the master constraint operator and $\Psi$ is the quantum state of the system. The master constraint operator is defined as

$$
\hat{M} = \int d^3x \left( \frac{\delta}{\delta \phi} \right)^2
$$

where $\phi$ is the field variable. The master constraint operator is densely defined on the kinematic Hilbert space $H_{Kin}$, but it is not defined on the physical Hilbert space $H_{Phys}$. This is because the master constraint operator is not a well-defined operator on the physical Hilbert space, but it is a well-defined operator on the kinematic Hilbert space.

The master constraint operator is closely related to the holographic principle. It suggests that the information about a system is not spread out throughout the system, but is instead concentrated on the boundary of the system. This is analogous to the way information is stored on a holographic film, where the information is encoded in the surface of the film, not in the volume of the film.

In conclusion, the holographic principle is a fundamental principle in quantum gravity that has been instrumental in the development of AdS/CFT. It suggests that the information about a system can be encoded in a lower-dimensional surface, and it has important implications for the structure of quantum space and the quantum master constraint.




### Subsection: 11.1b Holographic Entanglement Entropy and Quantum Information

Holographic entanglement entropy (HEE) is a concept that combines the principles of holography and quantum information. It is a measure of the entanglement between two subsystems in a quantum system, and it is particularly useful in the context of AdS/CFT.

#### Holographic Entanglement Entropy

Holographic entanglement entropy is a measure of the entanglement between two subsystems in a quantum system. It is defined as the Von Neumann entropy of the reduced density matrix for any of the subsystems. If the state describing two subsystems "A" and "B" is a separable state, then the reduced density matrix for either subsystem is a pure state, and the entropy is zero. However, if the reduced density matrix has a non-zero entropy, it indicates the existence of entanglement in the system.

Mathematically, if a state describing two subsystems $|\Psi_{AB}\rangle=|\phi_A\rangle|\phi_B\rangle$ is a separable state, then the reduced density matrix $\rho_A=\operatorname{Tr}_B|\Psi_{AB}\rangle\langle\Psi_{AB}|=|\phi_A\rangle\langle\phi_A|$ is a pure state. Thus, the entropy of the state is zero. Similarly, the density matrix of "B" would also have 0 entropy. A reduced density matrix having a non-zero entropy is therefore a signal of the existence of entanglement in the system.

#### Holographic Entanglement Entropy and Quantum Information

Holographic entanglement entropy plays a crucial role in quantum information theory. It provides a way to quantify the entanglement between two subsystems in a quantum system, which is a fundamental concept in quantum information theory. Furthermore, HEE is closely related to the holographic principle, which suggests that the information about a system can be encoded in a lower-dimensional surface. This connection between HEE and the holographic principle has led to the development of new insights into the nature of quantum systems.

In the context of AdS/CFT, HEE has been used to study the entanglement between different parts of the system. This has provided valuable insights into the structure of the system and the dynamics of entanglement in quantum systems. Furthermore, HEE has been used to study the behavior of black holes in AdS spaces, providing a new perspective on the information paradox in quantum gravity.

### Subsection: 11.1c Holography and Quantum Error Correction

Quantum error correction is a crucial aspect of quantum information theory, particularly in the context of quantum computing. It provides a way to protect quantum information from errors due to noise and other disturbances. In the context of holography, quantum error correction plays a significant role in ensuring the reliability and accuracy of quantum information retrieval.

#### Quantum Error Correction

Quantum error correction is a technique used to protect quantum information from errors due to noise and other disturbances. It involves encoding quantum information in a larger system, known as a quantum error-correcting code, which can detect and correct certain types of errors.

Mathematically, a quantum error-correcting code is a set of states $|\Psi_{AB}\rangle=|\phi_A\rangle|\phi_B\rangle$ that are protected from errors. If an error is introduced, it will affect the state of the system, but the error can be detected and corrected if the state remains within the code space.

One of the most significant applications of AdS/CFT in condensed matter physics is the description of the superfluid-insulator transition. This transition occurs in systems of electrically neutral atoms, such as liquid helium, when the atoms start to behave as a superfluid but then suddenly transition to an insulating state.

#### 12.1a Path Integral Formulation of QFT

The path integral formulation of QFT is a powerful mathematical tool that allows us to calculate the probability amplitude for a particle to transition from one state to another. It is based on the principle of superposition, which states that a particle can exist in multiple states simultaneously. The path integral formulation is particularly useful in quantum mechanics, where the state of a particle is described by a wave function.

The path integral formulation of QFT is based on the Feynman's path integral, which is given by

$$
Z[J]=\mathcal{N}\int \mathcal{D}\phi ~ e^{-i\int dt ~ [\mathcal{L}(t;\phi,\dot{\phi})+J(t)\phi(t)]}
$$

where $\mathcal{N}$ is the normalization factor, $\mathcal{D}\phi$ is the path integral measure, $\mathcal{L}(t;\phi,\dot{\phi})$ is the Lagrangian of the system, and $J(t)$ is the external driving source. The path integral measure $\mathcal{D}\phi$ is defined as

$$
\mathcal{D}\phi = \prod_{x} dx \prod_{t} d\phi(t)
$$

where $x$ is the position space and $t$ is the time. The external driving source $J(t)$ is introduced to account for the external influences on the system. It is important to note that $J(t)$ is an "external driving source" of $\phi(t)$, and not a source of $\phi(t)$.

G(t_1,\cdots,t_N)=\frac{\delta}{i\delta J(t_1)}\cdots\frac{\delta}{i\delta J(t_N)}Z[J]\Bigg|_{J=0}
$$

### Section: 12.1 Basics of Quantum Field Theory:

Quantum Field Theory (QFT) is a theoretical framework that combines quantum mechanics and special relativity to describe the behavior of particles and fields at the quantum level. It has been instrumental in the development of modern particle physics, providing a mathematical framework for understanding the behavior of particles at the subatomic level. QFT has been used to develop theories such as the Standard Model of particle physics, which describes the fundamental particles and their interactions.

#### 12.1a Path Integral Formulation of QFT

The path integral formulation of QFT is a powerful mathematical tool that allows us to calculate the probability amplitude for a particle to transition from one state to another. It is based on the principle of superposition, which states that a particle can exist in multiple states simultaneously. The path integral formulation is particularly useful in quantum mechanics, where the state of a particle is described by a wave function.

The path integral formulation of QFT is based on the Feynman's path integral, which is given by

$$
Z[J]=\mathcal{N}\int \mathcal{D}\phi ~ e^{-i\int dt ~ [\mathcal{L}(t;\phi,\dot{\phi})+J(t)\phi(t)]}
$$

where $\mathcal{N}$ is the normalization factor, $\mathcal{D}\phi$ is the path integral measure, $\mathcal{L}(t;\phi,\dot{\phi})$ is the Lagrangian of the system, and $J(t)$ is the external driving source. The path integral measure $\mathcal{D}\phi$ is defined as

$$
\mathcal{D}\phi = \prod_{x} dx \prod_{t} d\phi(t)
$$

where $x$ is the position space and $t$ is the time. The external driving source $J(t)$ is introduced to account for the external influences on the system. It is important to note that $J(t)$ is an "external driving source" of $\phi(t)$, and not a source of $\phi(t)$.

The path integral formulation of QFT allows us to calculate the Green's functions (correlators) of the system. These are given by

$$
G(t_1,\cdots,t_N)=\frac{\delta}{\delta J(t_1)}\cdots\frac{\delta}{\delta J(t_N)}Z[J]
$$

where $t_1,\cdots,t_N$ are the times at which the Green's functions are evaluated. The Green's functions provide information about the propagation of particles in the system, and are crucial for understanding the dynamics of the system.

#### 12.1b Feynman Diagrams and Perturbative QFT

Feynman diagrams are a powerful tool in quantum field theory, particularly in the context of perturbative quantum field theory. They provide a graphical representation of the interactions between particles, allowing us to visualize and calculate the probabilities of these interactions.

In perturbative quantum field theory, we start with a free theory, where the particles are non-interacting. The interactions between particles are then introduced as perturbations. These perturbations are represented by Feynman diagrams, which show the possible ways in which particles can interact with each other.

The rules for constructing Feynman diagrams are as follows:

1. Each line represents a particle.
2. Vertices where lines meet represent interactions between particles.
3. The direction of time is represented by the direction of the arrows on the lines.
4. The number of lines entering and leaving a vertex represents the number of particles involved in the interaction.

The probability amplitude for a Feynman diagram is given by the product of the interaction vertices, each with a factor of $g$, the coupling constant. The diagram is then summed over all possible diagrams for a given process.

The Feynman rules for perturbative quantum field theory are as follows:

1. For each vertex, include a factor of $g$.
2. For each line, include a factor of $i$.
3. For each loop, include a factor of $-i$.
4. Sum over all possible diagrams.

These rules allow us to calculate the probability amplitude for any process in perturbative quantum field theory. However, it is important to note that these calculations are only valid at the perturbative level, and do not take into account non-perturbative effects.

In the next section, we will discuss the concept of renormalization, which is crucial for making perturbative quantum field theory a consistent theory.

#### 12.1c Applications of QFT

Quantum Field Theory (QFT) has been instrumental in the development of modern particle physics, providing a mathematical framework for understanding the behavior of particles at the subatomic level. It has been used to develop theories such as the Standard Model of particle physics, which describes the fundamental particles and their interactions. In this section, we will explore some of the applications of QFT in particle physics.

##### 12.1c.1 The Standard Model

The Standard Model of particle physics is a QFT that describes the fundamental particles and their interactions. It is based on the principles of quantum mechanics and special relativity, and it has been successful in predicting the behavior of particles at the subatomic level.

The Standard Model includes three types of particles: quarks, leptons, and gauge bosons. Quarks and leptons are the matter particles, while gauge bosons are the force-carrying particles. The interactions between these particles are governed by the gauge symmetries of the theory, which are implemented through the gauge bosons.

The Standard Model also includes the Higgs boson, which is responsible for the phenomenon of particle mass. The discovery of the Higgs boson in 2012 at the Large Hadron Collider was a major milestone in particle physics, confirming a key prediction of the Standard Model.

##### 12.1c.2 Quantum Electrodynamics

Quantum Electrodynamics (QED) is a QFT that describes the interactions of particles with electromagnetic radiation. It is a fundamental theory in particle physics, and it has been instrumental in the development of modern technology, including the laser and the transistor.

In QED, the electromagnetic field is described as a collection of particles, the photons. The interactions between particles and photons are governed by the principles of quantum mechanics and special relativity. The theory has been extensively tested and has been found to be in excellent agreement with experimental data.

##### 12.1c.3 Quantum Chromodynamics

Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD) is a QFT that describes the interactions of particles with the strong nuclear force. It is a fundamental theory in particle physics, and it is responsible for the binding of quarks into particles such as protons and neutrons.

In QCD, the strong nuclear force is described as a gauge symmetry, similar to the electromagnetic force in QED. The theory has been extensively tested and has been found to be in excellent agreement with experimental data.

In the next section, we will explore the concept of renormalization, which is crucial for making QFT a consistent theory.

\mathcal{D}\phi = \prod_{x} dx \prod_{t} d\phi(t)

#### 12.1b Renormalization in QFT

Renormalization is a crucial aspect of Quantum Field Theory. It is a mathematical technique used to handle the divergences that arise in the calculation of physical quantities. These divergences occur when the integrals involved in the calculation become infinite. Renormalization allows us to redefine the parameters of the theory in such a way that the physical quantities remain finite.

The need for renormalization arises from the fact that the parameters of the theory, such as the coupling constant and the mass of the particles, are often dimensionful quantities. This means that they have units of length, time, or energy. However, in QFT, these parameters often appear in the denominators of the integrals, leading to potential divergences.

Renormalization is typically achieved through a process called "regularization", where the integrals are modified to make them finite. This is done by introducing a cutoff scale $\Lambda$ in the integral, which limits the range of integration. The integral is then evaluated as

$$
\int^\Lambda = \int_{-\infty}^\Lambda \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}e^{ipx}dp
$$

where $p$ is the momentum of the particle. The cutoff scale $\Lambda$ is then gradually increased until the integral converges. The final result is obtained by taking the limit $\Lambda \to \infty$.

Another approach to renormalization is dimensional regularization, where the dimension of space-time is analytically continued to a complex value. This allows the integrals to be evaluated in a way that avoids the need for a cutoff scale. However, this approach requires the use of the Beta function and the Gamma function, which can be complex and require careful handling.

In the next section, we will delve deeper into the concept of renormalization and discuss some of the challenges and controversies surrounding it.

#### 12.1c Renormalization and Regularization

Renormalization and regularization are two closely related concepts in Quantum Field Theory. As we have seen in the previous section, renormalization is a mathematical technique used to handle the divergences that arise in the calculation of physical quantities. Regularization, on the other hand, is a method used to make these calculations finite.

Regularization is typically achieved through a process called "cutoff regularization". In this method, the integral is made finite by specifying a cutoff scale $\Lambda > 0$. The integral to be evaluated is then given by

$$
\int^\Lambda = \int_{-\infty}^\Lambda \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}e^{ipx}dp
$$

where $p$ is the momentum of the particle. The cutoff scale $\Lambda$ is then gradually increased until the integral converges. The final result is obtained by taking the limit $\Lambda \to \infty$.

Another approach to regularization is "dimensional regularization". In this method, the dimension of space-time is analytically continued to a complex value. This allows the integrals to be evaluated in a way that avoids the need for a cutoff scale. However, this approach requires the use of the Beta function and the Gamma function, which can be complex and require careful handling.

The regularization process is crucial in Quantum Field Theory as it allows us to calculate physical quantities without encountering infinite values. However, it is important to note that the regularization scheme used can affect the final result. Therefore, it is necessary to choose a regularization scheme that is consistent with the physical principles of the theory.

### Section: 12.2 Renormalization Group Flow:

The renormalization group (RG) is a mathematical framework used in quantum field theory to study the behavior of physical systems at different scales. It is a powerful tool that allows us to understand the behavior of a system as we change the scale at which we observe it. The RG is particularly useful in quantum field theory, where the behavior of a system can be described by a set of parameters that change as we change the scale.

#### 12.2a Basics of Renormalization Group

The renormalization group is a group of transformations that leave the physical properties of a system invariant. These transformations are defined by a set of differential equations known as the renormalization group equations. The RG equations describe how the parameters of a system change as we change the scale at which we observe it.

The renormalization group is often used in conjunction with the block spin RG, a pedagogical picture of RG devised by Leo P. Kadanoff in 1966. The block spin RG is particularly useful in understanding the behavior of a system as we change the scale.

Consider a 2D solid, a set of atoms in a perfect square array, as depicted in the figure. Assume that atoms interact among themselves only with their nearest neighbours, and that the system is at a given temperature `T`. The strength of their interaction is quantified by a certain coupling `J`. The physics of the system will be described by a certain formula, say the Hamiltonian `H`.

Now proceed to divide the solid into blocks of 2×2 squares; we attempt to describe the system in terms of block variables, i.e., variables which describe the average behavior of the block. Further assume that, by some lucky coincidence, the physics of block variables is described by a "formula of the same kind", but with different values for `T` and `J` : `H_b`. (This isn't exactly true, in general, but it is often a good first approximation.)

Perhaps, the initial problem was too hard to solve, since there were too many atoms. Now, in the renormalized problem we have only one fourth of them. But why stop now? Another iteration of the same kind leads to `H_b`, and only one sixteenth of the atoms. We are increasing the observation scale with each RG step.

The best idea is to iterate until there is only one very big block. Since the number of atoms in any real sample of material is very large, this is more or less equivalent to finding the "long range" behaviour of the RG transformation which took and `H_b`. Often, when iterated many times, this RG transformation leads to a certain number of fixed points.

To be more concrete, consider a magnetic system (e.g., the Ising model), in which the `J` coupling denotes the trend of neighbour spins to be parallel. The configuration of the system is the result of the tradeoff between the ordering `J` term and the disordering effect of temperature.

For many models of this kind, the renormalization group equations can be solved exactly. The solutions often reveal the existence of a critical point, at which the system undergoes a phase transition. Near the critical point, the system exhibits power-law behavior, which is characterized by critical exponents. The renormalization group provides a powerful tool for studying these critical phenomena.

#### 12.2b Renormalization Group Equations

The renormalization group equations are a set of differential equations that describe how the parameters of a system change as we change the scale at which we observe it. These equations are derived from the principles of scale invariance and symmetry.

The renormalization group equations can be written in the following general form:

$$
\frac{d}{d\ln\Lambda} \mathbf{G}(\mathbf{x},\Lambda) = \mathbf{V}(\mathbf{x},\Lambda)
$$

where $\mathbf{G}(\mathbf{x},\Lambda)$ is the generating functional of the Green's functions, $\mathbf{x}$ is the set of fields and sources, and $\Lambda$ is the scale parameter. The function $\mathbf{V}(\mathbf{x},\Lambda)$ is the vertex function, which describes the interactions between the fields.

The renormalization group equations are used to study the behavior of a system as we change the scale at which we observe it. They allow us to understand how the parameters of a system change as we move from the microscopic to the macroscopic scale. This is particularly useful in quantum field theory, where the behavior of a system can be described by a set of parameters that change as we change the scale.

The renormalization group equations are also used to study the critical behavior of a system. Near the critical point, the system exhibits power-law behavior, which is characterized by critical exponents. The renormalization group provides a powerful tool for studying these critical phenomena.

In the next section, we will discuss the renormalization group flow, which is a graphical representation of the renormalization group equations. This will provide a more intuitive understanding of how the parameters of a system change as we change the scale.

#### 12.2c Renormalization Group Flow Diagrams

The renormalization group flow diagrams, also known as RG flow diagrams, are a graphical representation of the renormalization group equations. These diagrams provide a visual way to understand how the parameters of a system change as we change the scale at which we observe it.

The RG flow diagrams are constructed by plotting the values of the parameters of a system as a function of the scale parameter $\Lambda$. The horizontal axis of the diagram represents the scale, while the vertical axis represents the value of the parameter. The lines on the diagram represent the trajectories of the parameters as we change the scale.

The RG flow diagrams are particularly useful in understanding the critical behavior of a system. Near the critical point, the system exhibits power-law behavior, which is characterized by critical exponents. The RG flow diagrams allow us to visualize how these critical exponents change as we change the scale.

The RG flow diagrams are also useful in understanding the fixed points of the renormalization group equations. A fixed point is a point in the parameter space where the renormalization group equations are satisfied for all values of the scale. The RG flow diagrams allow us to visualize the basins of attraction of these fixed points, which are the regions in the parameter space where the system flows to the corresponding fixed point as we change the scale.

In the next section, we will discuss the concept of fixed points in more detail and how they relate to the critical behavior of a system.




### Section: 12.2 Renormalization Group Flow:

The renormalization group flow is a fundamental concept in quantum field theory and is closely related to the renormalization group (RG) equations. It describes the evolution of a physical system as we change the scale at which we observe it. The RG flow is particularly useful in understanding the behavior of a system as we change the scale, and it is often used in conjunction with the block spin RG.

#### 12.2b RG Flow and Fixed Points

The RG flow is a powerful tool for understanding the behavior of a physical system as we change the scale at which we observe it. It is particularly useful in quantum field theory, where the behavior of a system can be described by a set of parameters that change as we change the scale. The RG flow is often used in conjunction with the block spin RG, a pedagogical picture of RG devised by Leo P. Kadanoff in 1966.

Consider a 2D solid, a set of atoms in a perfect square array, as depicted in the figure. Assume that atoms interact among themselves only with their nearest neighbours, and that the system is at a given temperature `T`. The strength of their interaction is quantified by a certain coupling `J`. The physics of the system will be described by a certain formula, say the Hamiltonian `H`.

Now proceed to divide the solid into blocks of 2×2 squares; we attempt to describe the system in terms of block variables, i.e., variables which describe the average behavior of the block. Further assume that, by some lucky coincidence, the physics of block variables is described by a "formula of the same kind", but with different values for `T` and `J` : `H_b`. (This isn't exactly true, in general, but it is often a good first approximation.)

Perhaps, the initial problem was too hard, and we should have started with a simpler one. But now we have learned something: the block Hamiltonian `H_b` is a function of `T` and `J`, and these two parameters can be adjusted to make the block system look like the original system. This is the essence of the renormalization group flow: we start with a system at a certain scale, and then we flow to a fixed point in the space of theories. At this fixed point, the system looks the same at all scales, and we have achieved the goal of renormalization.

It is particularly useful in quantum field theory, where the behavior of a system can be described by a set of parameters that change as we change the scale. The RG flow is often used in conjunction with the block spin RG, a pedagogical picture of RG devised by Leo P. Kadanoff in 1966.

Consider a 2D solid, a set of atoms in a perfect square array, as depicted in the figure. Assume that atoms interact among themselves only with their nearest neighbours, and that the system is at a given temperature `T`. The strength of their interaction is quantified by a certain coupling `J`. The physics of the system will be described by a certain formula, say the Hamiltonian `H`.

Now proceed to divide the solid into blocks of 2×2 squares; we attempt to describe the system in terms of block variables, i.e., variables which describe the average behavior of the block. Further assume that, by some lucky coincidence, the physics of block variables is described by a "formula of the same kind", but with different values for `T` and `J` : `H_b`. (This isn't exactly true, in general, but it is often a good first approximation.)

Perhaps, the initial problem was too hard, and we should have started with a simpler one. But now we have learned something: the block Hamiltonian `H_b` is a function of `T` and `J`, and these two parameters can be adjusted to make the block system look like the original system. This is the essence of the renormalization group flow: we start with a system at a certain scale, and then we flow to a fixed point in the space of theories. At this fixed point, the system looks the same at all scales, and we have achieved the goal of renormalization.

### Section: 12.2c RG Flow in Quantum Gravity

Quantum gravity is a theoretical framework that combines quantum mechanics and general relativity. It is a fundamental theory that aims to describe the quantum nature of gravity and the universe as a whole. The renormalization group flow plays a crucial role in quantum gravity, particularly in the context of asymptotic safety.

#### 12.2c.1 Asymptotic Safety in Quantum Gravity

Asymptotic safety is a concept in quantum gravity that describes the behavior of the theory as we change the scale at which we observe it. It is a desirable property for a quantum theory of gravity, as it ensures the theory is well-defined and predictive at all scales. The concept of asymptotic safety is closely related to the renormalization group flow.

The renormalization group flow in quantum gravity can be described using the functional renormalization group equation (FRGE). The FRGE allows us to systematically construct nonperturbative approximations to the gravitational beta-functions by projecting the exact RG flow onto subspaces spanned by a suitable ansatz for the effective action.

#### 12.2c.2 The Einstein–Hilbert Truncation

The Einstein–Hilbert truncation is a specific ansatz for the effective action in quantum gravity. It is given by the Einstein–Hilbert action, where Newton's constant $G_k$ and the cosmological constant $\Lambda_k$ depend on the RG scale $k$. The effective action $\Gamma_k$ reads, for arbitrary spacetime dimension $d$,

$$
\Gamma_k[g,\bar{g},\xi,\bar{\xi}] = \frac{1}{16\pi G_k} \int\text{d}^d x\, \sqrt{g}\, \big( -R(g) + 2\Lambda_k \big) + \Gamma_k^\text{gf}[g,\bar{g}] + \Gamma_k^\text{gh}[g,\bar{g},\xi,\bar{\xi}] .
$$

Here, $R(g)$ is the scalar curvature constructed from the metric $g_{\mu\nu}$. Furthermore, $\Gamma_k^\text{gf}$ denotes the gauge fixing action, and $\Gamma_k^\text{gh}$ the ghost action with the ghost fields $\xi$ and $\bar{\xi}$.

The corresponding $\beta$-functions, describing the evolution of the dimensionless Newton constant $g_k=k^{d-2} G_k$ and the dimensionless cosmological constant $\lambda_k=k^{-2}\Lambda_k$, have been derived for the first time in reference for any value of the spacetime dimensionality, including the cases of $d$ below and above $4$ dimensions. In particular, in $d=4$ dimensions they give rise to the RG flow diagram shown on the left-hand side. The most important result is the existence of a non-Gaussian fixed point suitable for asymptotic safety. It is UV-attractive, meaning that the theory flows towards this fixed point as we increase the scale. This is a crucial result for quantum gravity, as it ensures the theory is well-defined and predictive at all scales.




### Section: 12.3 Conformal Field Theory:

Conformal Field Theory (CFT) is a quantum field theory that describes systems with conformal symmetry. This symmetry is a powerful tool that allows us to understand the behavior of quantum systems at different scales. In this section, we will explore the basics of Conformal Field Theory, including its definition, key concepts, and applications.

#### 12.3a Basics of Conformal Field Theory

Conformal Field Theory is a quantum field theory that describes systems with conformal symmetry. Conformal symmetry is a symmetry of space and time that preserves angles and ratios of lengths. In other words, it preserves the shape of objects, but not necessarily their size. This symmetry is particularly useful in quantum mechanics because it allows us to understand the behavior of quantum systems at different scales.

The key concept in Conformal Field Theory is the conformal block. A conformal block is a function that describes the contribution of a primary field and its descendants to a four-point function. It is defined as follows:

$$
G_p^{(s)}(x_i) = \sum_p C_{12p}C_{p34} G_p^{(s)}(x_i)
$$

where $C_{12p}$ and $C_{p34}$ are the three-point structure constants, and $G_p^{(s)}(x_i)$ is the conformal block. The conformal block depends on the fields $O_i$ and their positions, and it is determined by conformal symmetry. It can be computed using recursion relations and integrable techniques.

Conformal blocks obey the same conformal symmetry constraints as four-point functions. In particular, they can be written in terms of functions $g_p^{(s)}(u,v)$ of the cross-ratios. While the OPE $O_1(x_1)O_2(x_2)$ only converges if $|x_{12}|<\min(|x_{23}|,|x_{24}|)$, conformal blocks can be analytically continued to all (non pairwise coinciding) values of the positions.

Conformal Field Theory has many applications in quantum mechanics, including in the study of quantum gravity and the AdS/CFT correspondence. It is also used in the study of critical phenomena in condensed matter physics. In the next section, we will explore some of these applications in more detail.

#### 12.3b Conformal Symmetry and Crossing Symmetry

Conformal symmetry plays a crucial role in Conformal Field Theory. It allows us to understand the behavior of quantum systems at different scales, and it is particularly useful in the study of critical phenomena. In this subsection, we will explore the concept of crossing symmetry, a key consequence of conformal symmetry.

Crossing symmetry is a constraint on the spectrum of primary fields and the three-point structure constants in a Conformal Field Theory. It is a manifestation of the fundamental symmetry between space and time, and it is closely related to the concept of duality in quantum mechanics.

The crossing symmetry can be understood in terms of the OPE $O_1(x_1)O_2(x_2)$. Using this OPE, a four-point function can be written as a combination of three-point structure constants and s-channel conformal blocks,

$$
\left\langle \prod_{i=1}^4 O_i(x_i) \right\rangle = \sum_p C_{12p}C_{p34} G_p^{(s)}(x_i)
$$

The conformal block $G_p^{(s)}(x_i)$ is the sum of the contributions of the primary field $O_p$ and its descendants. It depends on the fields $O_i$ and their positions. If the three-point functions $\left\langle O_1O_2O_p\right\rangle$ or $\left\langle O_3O_4O_p\right\rangle$ involve several independent tensor structures, the structure constants and conformal blocks depend on these tensor structures, and the primary field $O_p$ contributes several independent blocks. Conformal blocks are determined by conformal symmetry, and known in principle. To compute them, there are recursion relations and integrable techniques.

Using the OPE $O_1(x_1)O_4(x_4)$ or $O_1(x_1)O_3(x_3)$, the same four-point function is written in terms of t-channel conformal blocks or u-channel conformal blocks,

$$
\left\langle \prod_{i=1}^4 O_i(x_i) \right\rangle = \sum_p C_{14p}C_{p23} G_p^{(t)}(x_i)
=\sum_p C_{13p}C_{p24} G_p^{(u)}(x_i)
$$

The equality of the s-, t-, and u-channel decompositions is called crossing symmetry: a constraint on the spectrum of primary fields, and on the three-point structure constants.

Conformal blocks obey the same conformal symmetry constraints as four-point functions. In particular, s-channel conformal blocks can be written in terms of functions $g_p^{(s)}(u,v)$ of the cross-ratios. While the OPE $O_1(x_1)O_2(x_2)$ only converges if $|x_{12}|<\min(|x_{23}|,|x_{24}|)$, conformal blocks can be analytically continued to all (non pairwise coinciding) values of the positions. In Euclidean space, conformal blocks are single-valued functions of the cross-ratios.

#### 12.3c Conformal Blocks and Crossing Symmetry

In the previous subsection, we introduced the concept of crossing symmetry and its relation to conformal symmetry. We also briefly mentioned the use of conformal blocks in the computation of four-point functions. In this subsection, we will delve deeper into the topic and explore the properties of conformal blocks and their role in crossing symmetry.

Conformal blocks, as we have seen, are the building blocks of four-point functions. They are the sum of the contributions of the primary field and its descendants. The conformal block $G_p^{(s)}(x_i)$ is determined by the fields $O_i$ and their positions. If the three-point functions $\left\langle O_1O_2O_p\right\rangle$ or $\left\langle O_3O_4O_p\right\rangle$ involve several independent tensor structures, the structure constants and conformal blocks depend on these tensor structures, and the primary field $O_p$ contributes several independent blocks.

Conformal blocks are determined by conformal symmetry, and known in principle. To compute them, there are recursion relations and integrable techniques. These techniques allow us to compute the conformal blocks for any primary field, given the conformal dimensions and OPE coefficients of the primary field and its descendants.

The crossing symmetry is a constraint on the spectrum of primary fields and the three-point structure constants in a Conformal Field Theory. It is a manifestation of the fundamental symmetry between space and time, and it is closely related to the concept of duality in quantum mechanics. The crossing symmetry can be understood in terms of the OPE $O_1(x_1)O_2(x_2)$. Using this OPE, a four-point function can be written as a combination of three-point structure constants and s-channel conformal blocks,

$$
\left\langle \prod_{i=1}^4 O_i(x_i) \right\rangle = \sum_p C_{12p}C_{p34} G_p^{(s)}(x_i)
$$

The equality of the s-, t-, and u-channel decompositions is called crossing symmetry: a constraint on the spectrum of primary fields, and on the three-point structure constants. This constraint is a powerful tool in the study of Conformal Field Theories, as it allows us to relate the properties of the theory in different channels.

We will also explore the quantum mechanics of systems, discussing how quantum mechanics applies to various physical systems, from atoms and molecules to more complex systems. We will examine how quantum mechanics can be used to describe the behavior of these systems, and how it can be used to make predictions about their future states.

Throughout this chapter, we will use mathematical notation to express these concepts. For example, the wave function of a quantum system is often denoted as $\Psi(x)$, and the Schrödinger equation is written as:

$$
i\hbar\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\Psi(x,t) = \hat{H}\Psi(x,t)
$$

where $\hat{H}$ is the Hamiltonian operator, $i$ is the imaginary unit, $\hbar$ is the reduced Planck constant, and $\frac{\partial}{\partial t}$ is the partial derivative with respect to time.

By the end of this chapter, you should have a solid understanding of the principles and theories of quantum mechanics, and be able to apply these concepts to the study of quantum systems.




### Subsection: 12.3b Conformal Bootstrap and CFT Correlation Functions

The conformal bootstrap method is a powerful tool in Conformal Field Theory that allows us to define and solve CFTs using only symmetry and consistency assumptions. This method reduces all correlation functions to combinations of structure constants and conformal blocks, providing exact solutions for certain CFTs and classifications of rational theories.

#### 12.3b.1 Structure Constants

Structure constants play a crucial role in Conformal Field Theory. They are defined as the coefficients in the three-point function of left- and right-primary fields. The three-point function is of the type

$$
\left\langle V_1(z_1)V_2(z_2)V_3(z_3) \right\rangle = C_{123} \times \frac{G_p^{(s)}(x_i)}{z_{12}^2z_{23}^2z_{31}^2}
$$

where $z_{ij} = z_i - z_j$ and $G_p^{(s)}(x_i)$ is the conformal block. The structure constants $C_{123}$ are independent of the positions $z_i$ and are called three-point structure constants.

The condition for the three-point function to be single-valued is that the left- and right-conformal dimensions of primary fields must obey

$$
\Delta_i - \bar \Delta_i \in \mathbb{Z} \quad \text{for bosonic fields}
$$

$$
\Delta_i - \bar \Delta_i \in \mathbb{Z} + \frac{1}{2} \quad \text{for fermionic fields}
$$

This condition is violated by parafermionic fields, whose correlation functions are therefore not single-valued on the Riemann sphere.

#### 12.3b.2 Conformal Blocks

Conformal blocks are functions that are determined by conformal symmetry and labelled by representations of the symmetry algebra. They play a crucial role in Conformal Field Theory as they allow us to write any correlation function as a linear combination of conformal blocks. The coefficients of this linear combination are products of structure constants.

In two-dimensional CFT, the symmetry algebra is factorized into two copies of the Virasoro algebra, and a conformal block that involves primary fields has a

$$
\Delta_i - \bar \Delta_i \in \mathbb{Q} \quad \text{for parafermionic fields}
$$

This condition leads to a rich structure of conformal blocks, which can be computed using recursion relations and integrable techniques.

#### 12.3b.3 Conformal Bootstrap

The conformal bootstrap method is a powerful tool that allows us to define and solve CFTs using only symmetry and consistency assumptions. It reduces all correlation functions to combinations of structure constants and conformal blocks, providing exact solutions for certain CFTs and classifications of rational theories.

The conformal bootstrap method is particularly useful in two dimensions, where it leads to exact solutions of certain CFTs and classifications of rational theories. This method is also used in the study of quantum gravity and the AdS/CFT correspondence.




### Subsection: 12.3c CFT and Holography

Conformal Field Theory (CFT) and holography are two fundamental concepts in modern physics. CFT is a quantum field theory that is invariant under conformal transformations, while holography is a principle that suggests that all the information about a system can be encoded in its boundary. In this section, we will explore the relationship between CFT and holography, and how they are used in string theory.

#### 12.3c.1 Holographic Duality

Holographic duality is a concept in string theory that suggests a deep connection between gravity and quantum mechanics. It proposes that the information about a system can be encoded in its boundary, rather than in its bulk. This principle is particularly useful in the context of CFT, where the boundary of a system is often easier to study than the bulk.

The holographic duality is implemented in string theory by the AdS/CFT correspondence. This correspondence states that a theory in Anti-de Sitter (AdS) space is dual to a CFT on the boundary of the AdS space. This duality has been extensively studied and has led to many important insights into the nature of quantum mechanics and gravity.

#### 12.3c.2 Holographic Renormalization

Holographic renormalization is a technique used to compute the expectation values of operators in a CFT. It is based on the holographic principle and the AdS/CFT correspondence. The basic idea is to map the problem of computing expectation values in the bulk to the problem of computing correlation functions on the boundary.

The holographic renormalization technique has been used to compute the expectation values of operators in various CFTs, including the three-dimensional Ising model and the two-dimensional minimal model. It has also been used to study the behavior of CFTs near their critical points, where the correlation functions exhibit power-law behavior.

#### 12.3c.3 Holographic Entanglement Entropy

Holographic entanglement entropy is a concept that combines the ideas of holography and entanglement entropy. It suggests that the entanglement entropy of a system can be computed from its boundary, rather than from its bulk. This concept has been extensively studied and has led to many important insights into the nature of quantum entanglement.

The holographic entanglement entropy is particularly useful in the context of CFT, where the entanglement entropy of a system can be difficult to compute due to the complexity of the system. The holographic entanglement entropy provides a way to compute the entanglement entropy of a system in a simpler and more tractable manner.

In conclusion, the concepts of CFT and holography are deeply intertwined in string theory. They provide powerful tools for studying quantum systems and have led to many important insights into the nature of quantum mechanics and gravity.

### 13.1 Quantum Fields in Black Hole Spacetime

In the previous section, we discussed the basics of black holes and their quantum properties. In this section, we will delve deeper into the quantum nature of black holes by exploring the concept of quantum fields in black hole spacetime.

Quantum fields are fundamental to our understanding of the quantum world. They are mathematical objects that describe the behavior of particles at the quantum level. In the context of black holes, quantum fields play a crucial role in understanding the behavior of particles near the event horizon.

The Schwarzschild solution, which describes the spacetime around a non-rotating black hole, is a useful starting point for understanding the behavior of quantum fields in black hole spacetime. The Schwarzschild solution is given by the following metric:

$$
ds^2 = -\left(1-\frac{2GM}{r}\right)dt^2 + \frac{dr^2}{1-\frac{2GM}{r}} + r^2d\theta^2 + r^2\sin^2\theta d\phi^2
$$

where $G$ is the gravitational constant, $M$ is the mass of the black hole, and $r$ is the radial coordinate.

The Schwarzschild solution is a solution to the Einstein field equations, which describe the relationship between gravity and matter. It is a static solution, meaning that it does not change over time. This is a key feature of black holes, as they are objects that do not change over time.

In the context of quantum fields, the Schwarzschild solution is particularly important. It allows us to understand the behavior of quantum fields near the event horizon of a black hole. The event horizon is the point of no return, where the gravitational pull is so strong that nothing, not even light, can escape.

The behavior of quantum fields near the event horizon is governed by the Schwarzschild solution. In particular, the metric components $g_{11}$ and $g_{44}$ are crucial in understanding the behavior of quantum fields. These components describe the behavior of particles in the radial and temporal directions, respectively.

The behavior of quantum fields near the event horizon is also influenced by the Christoffel symbols, which describe the curvature of spacetime. The Christoffel symbols for the Schwarzschild solution are given by the following matrix:

$$
\Gamma = \begin{bmatrix}
\frac{GM}{r^2} & 0 & 0 & 0\\
0 & \frac{1}{r} & 0 & 0\\
0 & 0 & \frac{1}{r\sin\theta} & 0\\
0 & 0 & 0 & 0
\end{bmatrix}
$$

The Christoffel symbols play a crucial role in understanding the behavior of quantum fields near the event horizon. They describe the curvature of spacetime, which is crucial in understanding the behavior of particles near the event horizon.

In the next section, we will explore the concept of Hawking radiation, a phenomenon that was first predicted by Stephen Hawking in the 1970s. We will explore the physics behind Hawking radiation and its implications for the quantum nature of black holes. We will also discuss the role of string theory and holographic duality in understanding Hawking radiation.





### Subsection: 13.1b Quantum Fields in Kerr Spacetime

The Kerr spacetime is a solution to the Einstein field equations that describes a rotating black hole. It is named after the physicist Roy Kerr, who first found the solution in 1963. The Kerr spacetime is a vacuum solution, meaning that it describes a black hole in the absence of any matter or radiation.

In the previous section, we discussed the quantum aspects of black holes in the context of the Schwarzschild spacetime. Now, we will extend our discussion to the Kerr spacetime and explore the quantum properties of rotating black holes.

#### 13.1b.1 Quantum Fields in Kerr Spacetime

The Kerr spacetime is a five-dimensional spacetime, with the coordinates $(t, r, \theta, \phi, x)$, where $t$ is time, $r$ is the radial coordinate, $\theta$ is the polar angle, $\phi$ is the azimuthal angle, and $x$ is an additional dimension that is not relevant for our discussion.

In the Kerr spacetime, the metric is given by:

$$
ds^2 = -\frac{\Delta}{\rho^2}dt^2 + \frac{\rho^2}{\Delta}dr^2 + \rho^2d\theta^2 + \frac{a^2\sin^2\theta}{\rho^2}(dt - a dr)^2 + \frac{\rho^2}{\Delta}a^2\sin^2\theta d\phi^2
$$

where $\Delta = r^2 - 2Mr + a^2$, $\rho^2 = r^2 + a^2\cos^2\theta$, and $a$ is the rotation parameter of the black hole.

The quantum fields in the Kerr spacetime are described by the Dirac equation, which is a relativistic wave equation that describes spin-1/2 particles, such as electrons. The Dirac equation in the Kerr spacetime is given by:

$$
\left(-i\gamma^\mu\partial_\mu + m\right)\psi = 0
$$

where $\gamma^\mu$ are the gamma matrices, $\partial_\mu$ are the partial derivatives, $m$ is the mass of the particle, and $\psi$ is the spinor field.

#### 13.1b.2 Quantum Aspects of Kerr Black Holes

The quantum aspects of Kerr black holes are similar to those of Schwarzschild black holes, but with an additional rotation parameter. The entropy of a Kerr black hole is given by the Bekenstein-Hawking entropy formula, but with an additional term that accounts for the rotation of the black hole. The Hawking radiation from a Kerr black hole is also modified by the rotation, leading to a spectrum of radiation that depends on the rotation parameter $a$.

The information paradox is also present in the context of Kerr black holes. The information paradox states that the information about the matter that falls into a black hole is lost forever, violating the principle of unitarity. This paradox is particularly intriguing in the context of Kerr black holes, as the rotation of the black hole seems to introduce a new degree of freedom that could potentially store the information.

In the next section, we will explore the quantum aspects of other types of black holes, such as the Reissner-Nordström black hole and the Kerr-Newman black hole.




### Subsection: 13.1c Quantum Fields in de Sitter Spacetime

The de Sitter spacetime is a solution to the Einstein field equations that describes a universe with positive cosmological constant. It is named after the physicist Willem de Sitter, who first found the solution in 1917. The de Sitter spacetime is a vacuum solution, meaning that it describes a universe in the absence of any matter or radiation.

In the previous section, we discussed the quantum aspects of black holes in the context of the Schwarzschild and Kerr spacetimes. Now, we will extend our discussion to the de Sitter spacetime and explore the quantum properties of the universe.

#### 13.1c.1 Quantum Fields in de Sitter Spacetime

The de Sitter spacetime is a four-dimensional spacetime, with the coordinates $(t, r, \theta, \phi)$, where $t$ is time, $r$ is the radial coordinate, $\theta$ is the polar angle, and $\phi$ is the azimuthal angle.

In the de Sitter spacetime, the metric is given by:

$$
ds^2 = -(1 - \frac{r^2}{R^2})dt^2 + \frac{dr^2}{1 - \frac{r^2}{R^2}} + r^2d\theta^2 + R^2\sin^2\theta d\phi^2
$$

where $R$ is the radius of curvature of the universe.

The quantum fields in the de Sitter spacetime are described by the Dirac equation, which is a relativistic wave equation that describes spin-1/2 particles, such as electrons. The Dirac equation in the de Sitter spacetime is given by:

$$
\left(-i\gamma^\mu\partial_\mu + m\right)\psi = 0
$$

where $\gamma^\mu$ are the gamma matrices, $\partial_\mu$ are the partial derivatives, $m$ is the mass of the particle, and $\psi$ is the spinor field.

#### 13.1c.2 Quantum Aspects of de Sitter Universe

The quantum aspects of the de Sitter universe are similar to those of the Schwarzschild and Kerr spacetimes, but with an additional cosmological constant. The entropy of the de Sitter universe is given by the Bekenstein-Hawking entropy formula, but with an additional term proportional to the cosmological constant.

The de Sitter universe is also characterized by a horizon, known as the cosmological horizon, which is located at $r = R$. This horizon is different from the event horizon of a black hole, as it is not a one-way membrane and does not trap information. However, it does play a crucial role in the quantum aspects of the de Sitter universe.

In the next section, we will explore the quantum aspects of the de Sitter universe in more detail, including the concept of quantum entanglement and the role of the cosmological horizon.
